scopecontent.p: John Fitch's autobiography (1 1/2 v.) and recollections of the proceedings "respecting the steam boat" (3 1/2 v.) were both written from 1790 to 1791 at the request of the Rev. Nathaniel Irwin. The autobiographical account touches on all his activities but mentions particularly his years as an apprentice, his captivity with the Indians and the British, and his entanglement in the affair between his business partner Henry Voight and Mary Kraft. Fitch's account of his development of the steamboat details his efforts to gain financial support and to secure patents. There is also an address, 1791 (1 v.), to the Commissioners of Congress for granting Exclusive Rights defending his invention claim, especially against James Rumsey.
